Subsection.Text: Where the Court finds that,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person’s improper conduct necessitated a motion under subsection (1), or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person improperly adjourned an examination under subsection (1),

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Court may direct the person to pay personally and forthwith the costs of the motion, any costs thrown away and the costs of any continuation of the examination and the Court may fix the costs and give such other direction as is just.

Heading.TitleText: Videotaping or other Recording of Examination

Subsection.Text: On consent of the parties or by direction of the Court, an examination may be recorded by videotape or other similar means and the tape or other recording may be filed for the use of the Court along with the transcript.
Section 111 applies, with necessary modifications, to a tape or other recording made under subsection (1).

Heading.TitleText: Sanctions for Default or Misconduct by Person to be Examined

Section.Text: Where a person fails to attend at the time and place fixed for an examination in the notice to attend or subpoena, or at the time and place agreed on by the parties, or refuses to take an oath or make an affirmation, to answer any proper question, to produce a document or thing that that person is required to produce or to comply with a direction under section 108, the Court may,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where an objection to a question is held to be improper, direct or permit the person being examined to reattend at that person’s own expense and answer the question, in which case the person shall also answer any proper questions arising from the answer,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the person is a party or, on an examination for discovery, a person examined on behalf of or in place of a party, dismiss the appeal or allow the appeal as the case may be,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: strike out all or part of the person’s evidence, including any affidavit made by the person, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: direct any party or any other person to pay personally and forthwith costs of the motion, any costs thrown away and the costs of any continuation of the examination.

Subsection.Text: It is the responsibility of a party who intends to refer to evidence given on an examination to have a copy of the transcript of the examination available for filing with the Court.
A copy of a transcript for the use of the Court at hearing shall not be filed until a party refers to it at hearing, and the presiding judge may read only the portions to which a party refers.
Where the person to be examined resides outside of Canada the Court may determine,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the examination is to take place in or outside of Canada,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the time and place of the examination,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum notice period,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the amount of witness fees and expenses to be paid to the person to be examined, and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter respecting the holding of the examination.

Subsection.Text: Where the person is to be examined outside of Canada, the direction under subsection (1) shall, if the moving party requests it, provide for the issuing of,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a commission (Form 112(2)(a)) authorizing the taking of evidence before a named commissioner, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a letter of request (Form 112(2)(b) — REQUEST) directed to the judicial authorities of the jurisdiction in which the person is to be found, requesting the issuing of such process as is necessary to compel the person to attend and be examined before the commissioner, and the direction shall be in Form 112(2)(b)A — DIRECTION.

Subsection.Text: The commission and letter of request shall be prepared and issued by the Registrar.

Where the person to be examined resides outside of Canada and is not a party or a person to be examined on behalf of or in place of a party, the examining party shall pay or tender to the person to be examined the amount of witness fees and expenses fixed under subsection (1).

A commissioner shall, to the extent that it is possible to do so, conduct the examination in the form of oral questions and answers in accordance with these rules, the laws of evidence of Canada and the terms of the commission, unless some other form of examination is required by the judgment or the law of the place where the examination is conducted.
As soon as the transcript of the examination is prepared the commissioner shall,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: return the commission, together with the original transcript and exhibits, to the Registrar who issued it,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a copy of the transcript and, where practicable, the exhibits, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: notify the parties who appeared at the examination that the transcript is complete and has been returned to the Registrar who issued the commission.

Subsection.Text: The Registrar shall send the transcript to the counsel for the examining party and the counsel shall, if requested, forthwith serve every other party with the transcript free of charge.

Heading.TitleText: Procedure on Examination for Discovery by Written Questions

Section.Text: An examination for discovery by written questions and answers shall be conducted by serving a list of the questions to be answered on the person to be examined. (Form 113)
Written questions shall be answered by the affidavit of the person being examined, served on the examining party within thirty days after service of the list of questions. (Form 114)
An objection to answering a written question shall be made in the affidavit of the person being examined, with a brief statement of the reason for the objection.

Subsection.Text: Where the examining party is not satisfied with an answer or where an answer suggests a new line of questioning, the examining party may, within fifteen days after receiving the answer, serve a further list of written questions which shall be answered within thirty days after service.

Where the person being examined refuses or fails to answer a proper question or where the answer to a question is insufficient, the Court may direct the person to answer or give a further answer to the question or to answer any other question either by affidavit or on oral examination.

Where the Court is satisfied, on reading all the answers to the written questions, that some or all of them are evasive, unresponsive or otherwise unsatisfactory, the Court may direct the person examined to submit to oral examination on such terms respecting costs and other matters as are just.

Where a person refuses or fails to answer a proper question on a written examination or to produce a document which that person is required to produce, the Court may, in addition to imposing the sanctions provided in subsections (2) and (3),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the person is a party or a person examined on behalf of or in place of a party, dismiss the appeal or allow the appeal as the case may be,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: strike out all or part of the person’s evidence, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: give such other direction as is just.

Section.Text: On motion by the person being examined, or by any party, the Court may terminate the written examination or limit its scope where,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the right to examine is being abused by an excess of improper questions, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the examination is being conducted in bad faith, or in an unreasonable manner so as to annoy, embarrass or oppress the person being examined.

Section.Text: Section 111 applies, with necessary modifications, to the filing of written questions and answers for the use of the Court.

Subsection.Text: A party who intends to introduce the evidence of a person at a hearing may, with leave of the Court or the consent of the parties, examine the person on oath or affirmation before the hearing for the purpose of having the person’s testimony available to be tendered as evidence at the hearing.
In exercising its discretion to direct an examination under subsection (1), the Court shall take into account,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the convenience of the person whom the party seeks to examine,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility that the person will be unavailable to testify at the hearing by reason of death, infirmity or sickness,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility that the person will be beyond the jurisdiction of the Court at the time of the hearing,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the expense of bringing the person to the hearing,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the witness ought to give evidence in person at the hearing, and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other relevant consideration.

Subsection.Text: Before moving for leave to examine an expert witness under subsection (1), the moving party shall serve on all other parties the report of the expert witness referred to in subsection 145(7) unless the Court directs otherwise.
Subject to subsection (2), sections 101 to 112 apply to the examination of a witness under section 119, unless the Court directs otherwise.
A witness examined under section 119 may be examined, cross-examined and re-examined in the same manner as a witness at a hearing.

Section.Text: Where a direction is given under section 119 for the examination of a witness outside of Canada, the direction shall, if the moving party requests it, provide for the issuing of a commission and letter of request under section 112 and for the taking of the evidence of the witness and, on consent of the parties, any other witness in the same jurisdiction, and the direction shall be in Form 112(2)(b)A — DIRECTION.

Subsection.Text: Any party may use at the hearing the transcript and a videotape or other recording of an examination under sections 119 and 121 as the evidence of the witness, unless the Court directs otherwise for any sufficient reason.
A witness whose evidence has been taken under section 119 or 121 shall not be called to give evidence at the hearing, except with leave of the judge.
Use of evidence taken under section 119 or 121 is subject to any ruling by the judge respecting its admissibility.
The transcript and a videotape or other recording may be filed with the Court at the hearing and need not be read or played at the hearing unless a party or the judge requires it.

Heading.TitleText: How Appeal is Set Down for Hearing

Subsection.Text: After the close of pleadings, any party to an appeal, who is not in default under these rules or a judgment of the Court and who is ready for hearing, may apply in writing to the Registrar to fix the time and place of hearing.
Where all parties agree on the making of a joint application, it shall be made in Form 123.

Where all parties do not agree on making a joint application, the party making the application shall file a memorandum containing the information, as far as the applicant is concerned, required in Form 123 and shall serve a copy of the memorandum on all other parties and those parties shall, within ten days of service of the memorandum, file and serve on the party applying a similar memorandum.
Subject to any direction by the Court, the Registrar, or a person designated by the Registrar or by the Chief Justice, may fix the time and place for the hearing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on receipt of a joint application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on receipt of an application and of a separate memorandum from each party; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on receipt of an application and after the time has expired for the filing of a separate memorandum by each party.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (4), the Court may, on its own initiative, fix the time and place for the hearing.
The Registrar shall forthwith send, by registered mail, notice of the time and place fixed for the hearing to all parties.

If the time and place for a hearing have been fixed on the joint application of the parties, the hearing shall not be adjourned unless the Court is satisfied that there are special circumstances that justify the adjournment and it is in the interests of justice to adjourn it.

If an appeal has not been set down for hearing or terminated by any means within 60 days after the filing of the reply or after the last day for the filing of the reply, whichever is later, subject to any direction by the Chief Justice, the Registrar or a person designated by the Registrar or by the Chief Justice may serve on the Deputy Attorney General of Canada and on the counsel of record for the appellant or, if the appellant acts in person, on the appellant, a notice of status hearing at least 30 days before the date fixed for that hearing, and the hearing shall be held before a judge.
A counsel who receives a notice of status hearing shall forthwith give a copy of the notice to that counsel’s client.

Unless the appeal has been set down for hearing or terminated by any means before the date fixed for the status hearing, the counsel of record shall attend the status hearing and the parties may attend the hearing.
Where a party represented by counsel does not attend the hearing, that counsel shall file proof that a copy of the notice was given to the party.
At the status hearing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if a reply has been filed, the judge may

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: set time periods for the completion of any remaining steps in the appeal,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: dismiss the appeal for delay, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: make any order or give any other direction that is appropriate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a reply has not been filed, the judge may,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: direct that the appeal be allowed if the facts alleged in the notice of appeal entitle the appellant to the judgment sought,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: direct that the appeal be heard on the basis that the facts alleged in the notice of appeal are presumed to be true and make a direction regarding the hearing fee, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: make any order or give any other direction that is appropriate.

Subsection.Text: The presumption in subparagraph (5)(b)(ii) is a rebuttable presumption.

Despite subsection (1), the Court may, on its own initiative or at the request of a party, at any time after the expiry of the period for serving a notice of status hearing provided in that subsection, direct counsel for the parties, either with or without the parties, and any party not represented by counsel, to appear before a judge who may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set time periods for the completion of any remaining steps before the hearing of the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determine the advisability of amending the pleadings;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: attempt to identify any issue and shorten the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: attempt to obtain admissions of fact or documents;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: consider directing that a settlement conference be held regarding any issue in the appeal;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: determine if the parties are ready to proceed with the hearing of the appeal by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: identifying the parties’ potential witnesses and the documents which may be filed as exhibits,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: confirming that all required steps in the appeal have been completed before setting down the appeal for hearing,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: determining the approximate duration of the hearing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: fixing a time and place for the hearing; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: make any other order or give any direction that the judge considers appropriate.

Subsection.Text: If a party fails to comply with an order made or direction given under subsection (5) or (7) or fails to appear at a status hearing at the time and place fixed for it, the Court may, on application or on its own initiative, allow or dismiss the appeal or make any other order that is appropriate.

The Chief Justice may, on his or her own initiative or at the request of a party, at any time order that an appeal or a group of appeals be subject to case management and may designate one or more judges to act as the case management judge.

The case management judge shall convene a case management conference as soon as possible after the close of pleadings for the purpose of establishing, in conjunction with the parties, a timetable for the conduct of the appeal or group of appeals.
The case management judge may deal with all issues that arise prior to the hearing of the appeal, including by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: convening case management conferences as necessary, either on their initiative or at the request of a party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: giving any directions that are necessary for the just, most expeditious and least expensive determination of the appeal on its merits, including consolidating two or more appeals or parts of appeals that raise common issues or deal with common facts;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: determining all motions that are made prior to the appeal hearing date or arranging for them to be heard by another judge;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: despite any other time requirement provided in these rules, setting the time for the completion of any steps in the appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: making any order or giving any direction that the case management judge considers appropriate.

Subsection.Text: If a party fails to comply with the time requirements set out in a timetable established under this section or with any requirement of these rules, or fails to attend any case management conference, the case management judge may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: strike out any document or portion of a document filed by that party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dismiss the appeal or give judgment in favour of the appellant;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: amend the timetable in order to allow the party to comply with it;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: order the party to pay costs, either in a fixed amount or in an amount to be taxed; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: make any other order that the case management judge considers just in the circumstances.

Subsection.Text: A case management judge hearing any motion may dispense in whole or in part with the requirement to file a notice of motion together with the affidavits or other documentary material.
A case management judge shall not preside at the hearing of the appeal except with the consent of the parties.
A trial management conference may be held as soon as a date for hearing the appeal has been fixed, at the request of one of the parties or on the initiative of the judge presiding at the hearing.
At the trial management conference, the judge may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obtain from the parties the names and contact information of the witnesses the parties intend to call and the substance of their testimony;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: consider the possibility of obtaining admissions that would facilitate proof of the non-contentious issues and the admission of documents whose authenticity is not in dispute;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: consider alternative methods of adducing evidence, including the filing of affidavits or reports;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: consider expeditious means for adducing evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: give directions that would facilitate the orderly and expeditious conduct of the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: identify and hear, if necessary, any pre-trial motions which the judge considers ought to be dealt with and disposed of before the hearing commences;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: address the issues referred to in subsection 145(9); and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: give any direction for the conduct of the hearing that the judge considers just in the circumstances.

Subsection.Text: The Court may, at any time, on its own initiative or at the request of a party, direct that a conference be held to consider the possibility of settling any or all of the issues.

The judge who presides at a settlement conference shall not preside at the hearing of the appeal and shall not communicate with the judge hearing the appeal concerning anything that was said or done at the settlement conference.
Unless otherwise directed by the settlement conference judge, the parties and their counsel, if the parties are represented by counsel, shall attend the settlement conference.
Each party shall, at least 14 days before the date of the settlement conference, serve on the other parties and submit to the Court a settlement conference brief containing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of the party’s theory of the case;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the material facts that the party expects to establish at the hearing of the appeal and how they will be established;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the issues to be determined at the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the law and authorities that the party will rely on at the hearing of the appeal.

Subsection.Text: A settlement conference brief shall not exceed 10 pages except with leave of the settlement conference judge, which may be applied for by informal communication with the Registry.
The settlement conference judge may adjourn a settlement conference and reconvene it at a later date.
At the conclusion of a litigation process conference held under section 125, subsection 126(2) or section 126.1,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: counsel or the parties, if they are not represented by counsel, may sign a memorandum setting out the results of the conference; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the judge presiding at the conference may give any direction that the judge considers necessary with respect to the conduct of the appeal.

Subsection.Text: Any memorandum signed by counsel or the parties, if they are not represented by counsel, or any direction given by the judge binds the parties unless the judge presiding at the hearing of the appeal directs otherwise.

Section.Text: No communication shall be made to the judge presiding at a hearing of an appeal or a motion in an appeal with respect to matters related to settlement or settlement discussions during a litigation process conference.
In sections 130 to 132, authenticity includes the fact that,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a document that is said to be an original was printed, written, signed or executed as it purports to have been,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a document that is said to be a copy is a true copy of the original, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the document is a copy of a letter, telegram, telecommunication or a fax, the original was sent as it purports to have been sent and was received by the person to whom it is addressed.

Heading.TitleText: Request to Admit Fact or Document

Subsection.Text: A party may, at any time, by serving a request to admit, request any other party to admit, for the purposes of the appeal only, the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document. (Form 130)
A copy of any document mentioned in the request to admit shall, where practical, be served with the request, unless a copy is already in the possession of the other party.
A party on whom a request to admit is served shall respond to it within fifteen days after it is served by serving on the requesting party, a response to request to admit. (Form 131)

Where the party on whom the request is served fails to serve a response as required by subsection (1), the party shall be deemed, for the purposes of the appeal only, to admit the truth of the facts or the authenticity of the documents mentioned in the request to admit.
A party shall also be deemed, for the purposes of the appeal only, to admit the truth of the facts or the authenticity of the documents mentioned in the request to admit, unless the party’s response

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specifically denies the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document mentioned in the request, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: refuses to admit the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document and sets out the reason for the refusal.

Section.Text: A party may withdraw an admission made in response to a request to admit, a deemed admission or an admission in the party’s pleading on consent or with leave of the Court.

Subsection.Text: A judge may exclude from a courtroom,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a witness until called to give evidence, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is interfering with the proper conduct of a hearing.

Subsection.Text: A direction under subsection (1) may not be made in respect of a party to the appeal or a witness whose presence is essential to instruct counsel for the party calling the witness, but the presiding judge may require any such party or witness to give evidence before any other witnesses are called to give evidence on behalf of that party.

Where an order is made excluding a witness from the courtroom, there shall be no communication to the witness of any evidence given during the absence of the witness from the courtroom, except with leave of the presiding judge, until after the witness has been called and has given evidence.

Where an appeal is heard in camera under the authority of an enactment, disclosure of information relating to the appeal is not contempt of court unless the Court has expressly prohibited the disclosure of the information.

Section.Text: Subject to any direction by the Chief Justice, at any time following the judgment, on requisition by the counsel or party who put an exhibit in evidence, or the person who produced it, the Registrar shall return the exhibit to the person making the requisition.

Subsection.Text: If at a hearing a party proposes to adduce evidence, the party or the party’s counsel shall, unless the judge directs otherwise, immediately before adducing the evidence, open his case by making a short statement giving a concise outline of the facts that the party proposes to prove and of the applicable law.
Unless the judge directs otherwise, the parties shall put in their respective cases by evidence or by putting before the Court the facts on which they rely, in the following order,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the respondent, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the appellant in respect of rebuttal evidence.

Subsection.Text: Unless the judge directs otherwise, after all parties have adduced their evidence, they shall be heard in argument in the order in which they adduced their evidence and the party who was first heard in argument may reply and an opposing party may answer a new point of law raised in the reply.

Section.Text: The judge may, in the presence of the parties or their counsel, inspect any place or thing concerning which any question may arise.
A judge may postpone or adjourn a hearing to such time and place and on such terms as are just.

Subsection.Text: The judge may reopen a hearing before judgment has been pronounced for such purposes and upon such terms as are just.

The judge may, at any time before judgment, draw the attention of the parties to any failure to prove some fact or document material to a party’s case, or to any defect in the proceeding, and permit a party to remedy the failure or defect for such purposes and upon such terms as are just.
Where a party shows that through no lack of diligence, a witness whose evidence is material has failed to attend the hearing, the judge may adjourn the hearing.

Upon an application for an adjournment under subsection (1) another party may require the party applying, on oath or on the oath of some other person, to state the facts that it is believed the witness would have stated, and the other party may admit those facts, or admit that the witness would have stated those facts and the judge may refuse to adjourn the hearing.
If at a hearing, either party fails to appear, the Court may allow the appeal, dismiss the appeal or give such other direction as is just.

The Court may set aside or vary, on such terms as are just, a judgment or order obtained against a party who failed to attend a hearing, a status hearing or a pre-hearing conference on the application of the party if the application is made within thirty days after the pronouncement of the judgment or order.

A party who requires the attendance of a person as a witness at a hearing may serve the person with a subpoena requiring the person to attend the hearing at the time and place stated in the subpoena and the subpoena may also require the person to produce at the hearing the documents or other things in the person’s possession, control or power relevant to the matters in question in the appeal that are specified in the subpoena. (Form 141(1))

Unless otherwise directed by the Court, a subpoena must be served on a person whose attendance is required at the hearing, at least five days before the day on which that person is required to appear.

On the request of a party or of counsel, the Registrar, or some other person authorized by the Chief Justice, shall sign, seal and issue a blank subpoena and the party or counsel may complete the subpoena and insert the names of any number of witnesses.
No subpoena for the production or an original record or document that may be proved by a certified copy shall be served without leave of the Court.

No person is required to attend at a hearing unless the subpoena has been served on that person personally in accordance with subsection (1.1) and, at the same time, witness fees and expenses calculated in accordance with Schedule II, Tariff A have been paid or tendered to the person.
Service of a subpoena and the payment or tender of the witness fees and expenses may be proved by affidavit.
A subpoena continues to have effect until the attendance of the witness is no longer required.

Where a witness whose evidence is material to a proceeding is served with a subpoena and the proper witness fees and expenses are paid or tendered to the witness, and the witness fails to attend the hearing or to remain in attendance in accordance with the requirement of the subpoena, the judge may by a warrant for arrest cause the witness to be apprehended and forthwith brought before the Court. (Form 141(7))

On being apprehended, the witness may be detained in custody until the presence of the witness is no longer required, or the witness is released on such terms as are just, and the witness may be ordered to pay the costs arising out of the failure to attend or remain in attendance.

Heading.TitleText: Compelling Attendance of Witness in Custody

Section.Text: The Court may direct the attendance as a witness of a person who is in the custody of any other person including the custodian of any of Her Majesty’s prisons. (Form 142)

Heading.TitleText: Evidence At Hearing of an Appeal

Subsection.Text: Before or at the hearing, the Court may direct that evidence of a particular fact shall be given in such manner and subject to such conditions as the Court may specify and in particular that the evidence shall be given,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by affidavit,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by statement on oath or affirmation of information and belief,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: by the production of documents or of entries in books or of copies thereof,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where a fact is a matter of common knowledge, either generally or in a particular place, by the production of a newspaper which contains a statement of that fact.

Subsection.Text: A direction made before the hearing under subsection (1) may be set aside or varied by the judge when it appears necessary to do so in the interests of justice.
Unless these rules provide otherwise, witnesses at a hearing shall be examined orally in Court and the examination may consist of direct examination, cross-examination and re-examination.

The judge shall exercise reasonable control over the mode of interrogation of a witness so as to protect the witness from undue harassment or embarrassment and may disallow a question put to a witness that is vexatious or irrelevant to any matter that may properly be enquired into at the hearing.
The judge may, at any time, direct that a witness be recalled for further examination.
Where a witness appears unwilling or unable to give responsible answers, the judge may permit the party calling the witness to examine him or her by means of leading questions.
In this section, expert report means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a solemn declaration made by a proposed expert witness under section 41 of the Canada Evidence Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a written statement signed by a proposed expert witness accompanied by a certificate of counsel indicating that counsel is satisfied that the statement represents evidence that the proposed expert witness is prepared to give in the matter; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a written statement in any other form authorized by direction of the Court in a particular case and for special reasons.

Subsection.Text: An expert report shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in full the evidence of the expert;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out the expert’s qualifications and the areas in respect of which it is proposed that they be qualified as an expert witness; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied by a certificate in Form 145(2) signed by the expert acknowledging that they have read the Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses set out in Schedule III and agree to be bound by it.

Subsection.Text: If an expert fails to comply with the Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses, the Court may exclude some or all of their expert report.
A party intending to call more than five expert witnesses at a hearing shall seek leave of the Court under section 7 of the Canada Evidence Act.
In deciding whether to grant leave, the Court shall consider all relevant matters, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the proceeding, its public significance and any need to clarify the law;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number, complexity and technical nature of the issues in dispute; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the likely expense involved in calling the expert witnesses in relation to the amounts in issue.

Subsection.Text: Two or more of the parties may jointly name an expert witness.
Unless otherwise directed by the Court, no evidence in chief of an expert witness shall be received at the hearing in respect of an issue unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the issue has been defined by the pleadings or by written agreement of the parties stating the issues;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: their expert report prepared in accordance with subsection (2) has been served on all other parties not less than 90 days before the commencement of the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the expert witness is available at the hearing for cross-examination.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (7), evidence in chief of an expert witness may be given at the hearing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by the reading of all or part of the expert report by the witness, unless the Court, with the consent of the parties, permits it to be taken as read; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the party calling the witness so elects, by the verbal testimony of the expert witness

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: explaining or demonstrating what is in the expert report or in the part that has been given in evidence, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of other matters, by special leave of the Court, if it considers it appropriate.

Subsection.Text: A litigation process conference other than a settlement conference may address

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any objection to the evidence of an adverse party’s proposed expert witness and the basis of the objection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any benefit to the conduct of the proceeding that would be achieved by ordering that the proposed expert witnesses confer with one another before the hearing in order to narrow the issues and identify the points on which their views differ;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the need for any additional or rebuttal expert witness evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of proposed expert witnesses and the manner of presentation of their evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other issue arising from the expert reports of proposed expert witnesses.

Subsection.Text: The Court, at the request of a party or on its own initiative, may at any time order that expert witnesses confer with one another before the hearing in order to narrow the issues and identify the points on which their views differ.
The parties and their counsel may attend an expert conference but the conference may take place in the parties’ absence if the parties agree.
The Court may order that an expert conference take place in the presence of a judge.
A joint statement prepared by two or more expert witnesses following an expert conference is admissible in evidence at the hearing.

Discussions in an expert conference and documents prepared for the conference are confidential and shall not be disclosed to the judge presiding at the hearing of the appeal except with consent of the parties.

Unless otherwise directed by the Court, no evidence of an expert witness, including their expert report, shall be led in rebuttal of any evidence referred to in paragraph (7)(b) unless the rebuttal evidence has been reduced to writing in accordance with this section and a copy is served on the other parties not less than 60 days before the commencement of the hearing.

Unless otherwise directed by the Court, no evidence of an expert witness, including an expert report, shall be led in surrebuttal of any evidence tendered under subsection (15) unless the surrebuttal evidence has been reduced to writing in accordance with this section and a copy has been served on the other parties not less than 30 days before the commencement of the hearing.

The Court may require that some or all of the expert witnesses testify as a panel after the completion of the testimony of the non-expert witnesses of each party or at any other time that the Court determines.
The Court may identify matters that are within the area of expertise of the panel members and pose questions to the panel members about those matters.

Expert witnesses shall give their views and may be directed to comment on the views of other panel members and to make concluding statements. They may, with leave of the Court, pose questions to other panel members.
On completion of the testimony of the panel, panel members may be cross-examined and re-examined in the sequence directed by the Court.
A party may secure the attendance of a person who is,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an adverse party, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an officer, director or employee of an adverse party,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: as a witness at a hearing by,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: serving the person with a subpoena, or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: serving on the adverse party or the counsel of record for the adverse party, at least five days before the commencement of the hearing, a notice of intention to call the person as a witness,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and at the same time, paying or tendering witness fees and expenses calculated in accordance with Schedule II, Tariff A.

Subsection.Text: Where a person referred to in subsection (1) is in attendance at the hearing a party may call the person as a witness without previous notice or the payment of witness fees and expenses.
A party calling a witness referred to in subsection (1) may cross-examine the witness.
Where a person required to testify under this section,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: refuses or neglects to attend at the hearing or to remain in attendance at the hearing,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: refuses to be sworn, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: refuses to answer any proper question put to that person or to produce any document or other thing which that person is required to produce,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the Court may grant judgment in favour of the party calling the witness, adjourn the hearing or give such other direction as is just.

Subsection.Text: This section applies if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two or more appeals have been filed before the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Court has not made a decision disposing of any of the appeals; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the appeals give rise to one or more common or related issues of fact or law.

Subsection.Text: The Court may give a direction

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specifying one or more of the appeals referred to in subsection (1) as a lead case or lead cases; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: staying the related appeals.

Subsection.Text: If the Court gives a direction, each party in a related appeal who agrees to be bound, in whole or in part, by the decision in the lead case shall, within 10 days, file Form 146.1 with the Court.

If a party does not agree to be bound by the decision in the lead case, in whole or in part, or does not file Form 146.1 with the Court, the Court shall give a direction that the appeal is no longer stayed.
The Court may, on its own initiative or at the request of a party, give directions with respect to the related appeals, provide for their disposal or take further steps with respect to those appeals.
If a lead case or lead cases are withdrawn or disposed of before the Court makes a decision in relation to the common or related issues, the Court shall give directions as to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether another appeal or other appeals are to be heard as the lead case or lead cases; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether any direction affecting the related appeals should be set aside or amended.

Subsection.Text: The Court may determine the amount of the costs of all parties involved in any proceeding, the allocation of those costs and the persons required to pay them.
Costs may be awarded to or against the Crown.
In exercising its discretionary power pursuant to subsection (1) the Court may consider,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the result of the proceeding,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts in issue,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the importance of the issues,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any offer of settlement made in writing,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the volume of work,

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the complexity of the issues,

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of any party that tended to shorten or to lengthen unnecessarily the duration of the proceeding,

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the denial or the neglect or refusal of any party to admit anything that should have been admitted,

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: whether any stage in the proceedings was,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: improper, vexatious, or unnecessary, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: taken through negligence, mistake or excessive caution,

Paragraph.Label: (i.1)
Paragraph.Text: whether the expense required to have an expert witness give evidence was justified given

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the nature of the proceeding, its public significance and any need to clarify the law,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the number, complexity or technical nature of the issues in dispute, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the amount in dispute; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter relevant to the question of costs.

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise ordered by the Court, if an appellant makes an offer of settlement and obtains a judgment as favourable as or more favourable than the terms of the offer of settlement, the appellant is entitled to party and party costs to the date of service of the offer and substantial indemnity costs after that date, as determined by the Court, plus reasonable disbursements and applicable taxes.

Unless otherwise ordered by the Court, if a respondent makes an offer of settlement and the appellant obtains a judgment as favourable as or less favourable than the terms of the offer of settlement or fails to obtain judgment, the respondent is entitled to party and party costs to the date of service of the offer and substantial indemnity costs after that date, as determined by the Court, plus reasonable disbursements and applicable taxes.
Subsections (3.1) and (3.2) do not apply unless the offer of settlement

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is served no earlier than 30 days after the close of pleadings and at least 90 days before the commencement of the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is not withdrawn; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: does not expire earlier than 30 days before the commencement of the hearing.

Subsection.Text: A party who is relying on subsection (3.1) or (3.2) has the burden of proving that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is a relationship between the terms of the offer of settlement and the judgment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the judgment is as favourable as or more favourable than the terms of the offer of settlement, or as favourable or less favourable, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of this section, substantial indemnity costs means 80% of solicitor and client costs.

In ascertaining whether the judgment granted is as favourable as or more favourable than the offer of settlement for the purposes of applying subsection (3.1) or as favourable as or less favourable than the offer of settlement for the purposes of applying subsection (3.2), the Court shall not have regard to costs awarded in the judgment or that would otherwise be awarded, if an offer of settlement does not provide for the settlement of the issue of costs.

For greater certainty, if an offer of settlement that does not provide for the settlement of the issue of costs is accepted, a party to the offer may apply to the Court for an order determining the amount of costs.

No communication respecting an offer of settlement shall be made to the Court, other than to a judge in a litigation process conference who is not the judge at the hearing, until all of the issues, other than costs, have been determined.
The Court may fix all or part of the costs with or without reference to Schedule II, Tariff B and, further, it may award a lump sum in lieu of or in addition to any taxed costs.
Notwithstanding any other provision in these rules, the Court has the discretionary power,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to award or refuse costs in respect of a particular issue or part of a proceeding,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to award a percentage of taxed costs or award taxed costs up to and for a particular stage of a proceeding, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to award all or part of the costs on a solicitor and client basis.

Subsection.Text: The Court may give directions to the taxing officer and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the Court in any particular proceeding may give directions,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respecting increases over the amounts specified for the items in Schedule II, Tariff B,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting services rendered or disbursements incurred that are not included in Schedule II, Tariff B, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to permit the taxing officer to consider factors other than those specified in section 154 when the costs are taxed.

Subsection.Text: Any party may,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: within thirty days after the party has knowledge of the judgment, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after the Court has reached a conclusion as to the judgment to be pronounced, at the time of the return of the motion for judgment,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: whether or not the judgment included any direction concerning costs, apply to the Court to request that directions be given to the taxing officer respecting any matter referred to in this section or in sections 148 to 152 or that the Court reconsider its award of costs.

Section.Text: Where under section 16.2 of the Act a party has discontinued a proceeding, the other party may tax the costs thereof and, if the taxed costs are not paid within four days after taxation, may enforce payment as if judgment therefor had been granted.

Where a proceeding is settled on the basis that a party shall pay or recover costs and the amount of costs is not included in or determined by the settlement, the costs may be taxed under sections 153 to 159 on the filing of a copy of the minutes of settlement in the Registry.

Heading.TitleText: Costs on Failure to Elect under Subsection 18(1) of the Act

Section.Text: On an appeal under the Income Tax Act, the Court may refuse or reduce costs otherwise payable to an appellant who, in circumstances in which the appellant could make an election under subsection 18(1) of the Act, does not make such an election.
Subject to the directions of the Court costs shall be taxed under sections 153 to 159.

Subsection.Text: Unless the Court otherwise directs, and whatever the result of the proceeding,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of and occasioned by an amendment of a pleading made without leave shall be borne by the party making the amendment,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of or occasioned by an application to extend the time fixed by these rules or by a direction for doing an act, shall be borne by the party making the application,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of proving a document shall be borne by the party proving the document, if no request to admit the authenticity of the document was served under section 130,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of proving a document shall be allowed to the party proving the document if a request to admit the authenticity of the document was served under section 130 and the authenticity of the document was not admitted, and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the costs of proving a fact shall be allowed to the party proving the fact, if a request to admit the fact was served under section 130 and the fact was not admitted, and the failure to do so has not been found by the Court to have been based on reasonable grounds.

Subsection.Text: Upon a taxation, such costs as may be allowed under subsection (1) shall be allowed, by way of set off or otherwise, without a special direction.
Where a counsel for a party has caused costs to be incurred improperly or without reasonable cause or to be wasted by undue delay, misconduct or other default, the Court may make a direction,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: disallowing some or all of the costs as between the counsel and the client,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: directing the counsel to reimburse the client for any costs that the client has been ordered to pay to any other party, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: requiring the counsel to indemnify any other party against costs payable by that party.

Subsection.Text: A direction under subsection (1) may be made by the Court on its own initiative or on the motion of any party to the proceeding, but no such direction shall be made unless the counsel is given a reasonable opportunity to make representations to the Court.
The Court may direct that notice of a direction against a counsel under subsection (1) be given to the client in the manner specified in the direction.

Section.Text: Where a judge has made an order under section 19.1 of the Act, costs may be awarded against the person in respect of whom the order has been made.

Subsection.Text: The taxing officer shall be the Registrar and any other officer of the Registry designated by the Chief Justice as a taxing officer.
Where for any reason there would otherwise be a delay in the taxation of a bill of costs, a judge may tax the bill of costs.

The taxing officer may direct that the taxation of a bill of costs be conducted by teleconference, by videoconference or by a combination of both and may specify the party responsible for establishing the communication.

Section.Text: Where party and party costs are to be taxed, the taxing officer shall tax and allow the costs in accordance with Schedule II, Tariff B and the officer shall consider,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts in issue,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the importance of the issues,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the complexity of the issues,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the volume of work, and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that the Court has directed the taxing officer to consider.

Heading.TitleText: Taxation at Instance of Party Entitled

Subsection.Text: A party entitled to costs may obtain a notice of appointment for taxation of costs from the appropriate taxing officer on filing with the taxing officer a bill of costs and a copy of the direction or other document giving rise to the party’s entitlement to costs. (Form 155)
The notice and the bill of costs shall be served on every party interested in the taxation at least seven days before the date fixed for the taxation.

Heading.TitleText: Taxation at Instance of Party Liable

Subsection.Text: Where a party entitled to costs fails or refuses to file or serve a bill of costs for taxation within a reasonable time, any party liable to pay the costs may obtain a notice to deliver a bill of costs for taxation from the appropriate taxing officer. (Form 156)
The notice shall be served on every party interested in the taxation, at least twenty-one days before the date fixed for the taxation.

On being served with the notice, the person required to deliver a bill of costs shall file and serve a copy of the bill on every party interested in the taxation, at least seven days before the date fixed for the taxation.

Where a party required to deliver a bill of costs for taxation fails to do so at the time set out in the notice, and thereby prejudices another party, the taxing officer may fix the costs of the defaulting party at an appropriate sum in order to prevent further prejudice to the other party.
A taxing officer may direct production of books and documents and give directions for the conduct of a taxation.
The taxing officer may, in his or her discretion, award or refuse the costs of a taxation to either party, and fix those costs.
No disbursements other than fees paid to the Registry shall be taxed or allowed unless it is established that the disbursement was made or that the party is liable for it.

The taxing officer may allow all services, sales, use or consumption taxes and other like taxes paid or payable on any counsel fees and disbursements allowed if it is established that such taxes have been paid or are payable and are not otherwise reimbursed or reimbursable in any manner whatever, including, without restriction, by means of claims for input tax credits in respect of such taxes.

Section.Text: On the taxation of costs, the taxing officer shall set out in a certificate of costs the amount of costs taxed and allowed. (Form 158)
Upon motion of a party who is dissatisfied with the taxation, made within thirty days of the date of a certificate of costs, the Court may review the taxation and give such direction as may be just.
Where it appears that the appellant is resident outside of Canada, the Court on application by the respondent may give such direction regarding security for costs as is just.
An application for security for costs may be made only after the respondent has delivered a reply to the notice of appeal.
The amount and form of security and the time for payment into Court or otherwise giving the required security shall be determined by the Court.
An appellant who has been directed to give security for costs may not, until the security has been given, take any step in the appeal unless the Court directs otherwise.
Where the appellant defaults in giving the security required, the Court on application may dismiss the appeal.
The amount of security may be increased or decreased at any time.
On giving the security required, the appellant shall forthwith give notice of compliance to the respondent.

Heading.TitleText: Payment Into and Out of Court

Subsection.Text: A person who pays money into Court shall do so by delivering to the Registry

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a bill of exchange drawn on a bank, trust company, credit union or caisse populaire, or such other bill of exchange as may be authorized by order of the Court, that is payable to the order of the Receiver General of Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: three copies of a tender of payment into Court. (Form 166.1)

Subsection.Text: A payment into Court is effective on the day the bill of exchange is paid after presentation for payment.
Where a payment is effective, the Registry shall return a copy of the tender of payment into Court to the person making the payment.

Where an order has been made by the Court for payment out of court of money that is in the Consolidated Revenue Fund, or for payment out of any such money, together with any interest that may have accumulated on it, a requisition shall be made by the Registry to the Receiver General for such payment.

A requisition shall be for an instrument in the amount to be paid out and payable to the person to whom the money is to be paid pursuant to the order, to be sent to the Registry at Ottawa, or at such other place as may be specified, for delivery of the instrument to the payee’s counsel of record, if the payee has such a counsel, and otherwise for delivery to the payee.

Heading.TitleText: Judgments Disposing of an Appeal or an Interlocutory Application

Subsection.Text: The Court shall dispose of an appeal or an interlocutory or other application that determines in whole or in part any substantive right in dispute between or among the parties by rendering a judgment and shall dispose of any other interlocutory or other application by issuing an order.
A judgment shall be dated on the day it is signed and that day is the date of the pronouncement of the judgment.
A judgment and the reasons relating to it, if any, shall be deposited with the Registry without delay.

Heading.TitleText: Reconsideration of a Judgment on an Appeal

Section.Text: Where the Court has pronounced a judgment disposing of an appeal any party may within ten days after that party has knowledge of the judgment, move the Court to reconsider the terms of the judgment on the grounds only,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the judgment does not accord with the reasons for judgment, if any, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that some matter that should have been dealt with in the judgment has been overlooked or accidentally omitted.

Heading.TitleText: Direction for and Approval of Draft Judgment

Subsection.Text: The Court may direct that one of the parties prepares a draft of an appropriate judgment to implement the Court’s decision.

Where a party has been directed to prepare a draft of a judgment and all parties represented at the hearing have approved the form of the judgment by signing the original or a copy of it, the party who prepared the draft judgment shall,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: file the original or the copy or copies approved by the parties, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: leave the original judgment with the Registrar for signing by the Court.

Subsection.Text: Where the party directed to draft the judgment is unable to obtain the approval of every other party represented at the hearing, any party may apply to the judge who presided at the hearing to settle the terms of the judgment and to give any necessary directions, and upon settlement the judge shall sign the judgment and deposit it in the Registry.

Heading.TitleText: Judgments by Consent on an Appeal

Section.Text: When all parties have consented in writing to a judgment disposing of an appeal, the Court may,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: grant the judgment sought without a hearing,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: direct a hearing, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: direct that written representations be filed.

Heading.TitleText: Judgments on Admissions or Certain Documentary Evidence

Section.Text: A party may, at any stage of a proceeding, apply for judgment in respect of any matter

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: upon any admission in the pleadings or other documents filed in the Court, or in the examination of another party, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of which the only evidence consists of documents and such affidavits as are necessary to prove the execution or identity of the documents,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: without waiting for the determination of any other question between the parties.

Heading.TitleText: Setting Aside, Varying or Amending Interlocutory Judgments

Subsection.Text: A person who,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is affected by a judgment obtained on motion without notice, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fails to appear on a motion through accident, mistake or insufficient notice,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: may move to set aside or vary the judgment by a notice of motion.

Subsection.Text: On a motion under subsection (1) the Court may set aside or vary the judgment on such terms as are just.
A motion under subsection (1) shall not be made,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: after the expiry of a reasonable time after the moving party knows or ought reasonably to have known of the judgment, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the moving party has taken any further steps in the proceeding after obtaining knowledge of the judgment,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: except with leave of the Court.

Heading.Label: Setting Aside, Varying or Amending Accidental Errors in Judgments — General

Subsection.Text: A judgment that,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contains an error arising from an accidental slip or omission, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: requires amendment in any matter on which the Court did not adjudicate,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: may be amended by the Court on application or of its own motion.

Subsection.Text: A party who seeks to,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a judgment set aside or varied on the ground of fraud or of facts arising or discovered after it was made,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: suspend the operation of a judgment, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: obtain other relief than that originally directed,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: may make a motion for the relief claimed.

Subsection.Text: In addition to any other method of enforcement available, a judgment directing the payment of money to Her Majesty in right of Canada may be enforced by a writ of seizure and sale of the real and personal property of the person required to make payment or by the garnishment of debts payable to such person by another person.
A writ of seizure and sale or a notice of garnishment may be issued by a judge of the Court on application by the Deputy Attorney General of Canada, which application may be made ex parte.
An application for one or more writs of seizure and sale may be made under subsection (2) and it shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and amount of any payment received since the judgment was issued, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amount owing, including interest and the rate of interest,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and any other evidence necessary to establish the amount awarded and the amount owing.

Subsection.Text: An application for one or more notices of garnishment may be made under subsection (2) and it shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and amount of any payment received since the judgment was issued,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amount owing, including interest and the rate of interest,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of each person to whom a notice of garnishment is to be directed,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that the deponent believes that those persons are or will become indebted to the debtor and the grounds for the belief,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: such particulars of the debts as are known to the deponent, and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: where a person to whom a notice of garnishment is to be directed is not then indebted but will become indebted to the debtor, such particulars of the date on which and the circumstances under which the debt will arise as are known to the deponent, and

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: any other evidence necessary to establish the amount awarded and the amount owing.

Subsection.Text: A writ of seizure and sale or a notice of garnishment shall be in a form approved by the judge who hears the application under subsection (2) and the judge may give such directions with respect to the matter as the judge considers just and necessary in the circumstances.

Where a judgment directs the payment of money by and to a person, neither of whom is Her Majesty in right of Canada, the person entitled to payment may make application to a judge of the Court for a writ of seizure and sale or a notice of garnishment, which application may be made ex parte.
Subsections (3) to (5) apply to an application made under subsection (6).

Where a judgment directs the payment of money to Her Majesty in right of Canada, the Deputy Attorney General of Canada may make application to the Court, which application may be made ex parte, for an order directing the examination of the judgment debtor.

The Court may order the judgment debtor or, if the judgment debtor is a body corporate, one of its officers, to attend before the Registrar or such other officer of the Court as the Registrar may appoint, and be orally examined on the questions

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: as to all the property that the judgment debtor possesses or has possessed since incurring the obligation that was the basis of the judgment or order, and as to the judgment debtor’s sources of income, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: without limiting the generality of paragraph (a), whether any and, if so, what debts are owing to the judgment debtor,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: and the Court may also order the judgment debtor or officer to produce any books or documents in the possession or control of the judgment debtor relevant to those questions at the time and place appointed for the examination.

Subsection.Text: An order under this section must be served personally on the judgment debtor and on any officer of a body corporate ordered to attend for examination.

Any difficulty arising in the course of an examination under this section before the Registrar or other officer, including any dispute with respect to the obligation of the person being examined to answer any question put to that person, may be referred to the Court, and the Court may determine it or give such directions for determining it as the Court thinks fit.

Where a judgment directs the payment of money by and to a person, neither of whom is Her Majesty in right of Canada, the person entitled to payment may make application to the Court, which application may be made ex parte, for an order directing the examination of the judgment debtor.
Subsections 172.2(2) to (4) apply to an application made under subsection (1).
A person is guilty of contempt of court who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at a hearing of the Court fails to maintain a respectful attitude, remain silent or refrain from showing approval or disapproval of the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: wilfully disobeys a process or order of the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: acts in such a way as to interfere with the orderly administration of justice or to impair the authority or dignity of the Court;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is an officer of the Court and fails to perform his or her duties;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is a sheriff or bailiff and does not execute a writ forthwith or does not make a return thereof; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: contrary to these rules and without lawful excuse,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: refuses or neglects to obey a subpoena or to attend at the time and place appointed for his or her examination for discovery,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: refuses to be sworn or to affirm or to answer any question put to him or her,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: refuses or neglects to produce or permit to be inspected any document or other property, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: refuses or neglects to answer interrogatories or to make discovery of documents.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (6), before a person may be found in contempt of court, the person alleged to be in contempt shall be served with an order, made on the motion of a person who has an interest in the proceeding or at the Court’s own initiative, requiring the person alleged to be in contempt

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to appear before a judge at a time and place stipulated in the order;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to be prepared to hear proof of the act with which the person is charged, which shall be described in the order with sufficient particularity to enable the person to know the nature of the case against the person; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to be prepared to present any defence that the person may have.

Subsection.Text: A motion for an order under subsection (2) may be made ex parte.
An order may be made under subsection (2) if the Court is satisfied that there is a prima facie case that contempt has been committed.
An order under subsection (2) shall be personally served, together with any supporting documents, unless otherwise ordered by the Court.

In a case of urgency, a person may be found in contempt of court for an act committed in the presence of a judge in the exercise of his or her functions and condemned at once, provided that the person has first been called on to justify his or her behaviour.
A finding of contempt shall be based on proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
A person alleged to be in contempt may not be compelled to testify.
Where the Court considers it necessary, it may request the assistance of the Attorney General of Canada or any other person in relation to any proceedings for contempt.
Where a person is found to be in contempt, a judge may order, in addition to any other order made in respect of the proceedings, any or all of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the person be imprisoned for a period of less than two years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that the person pay a fine;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that the person do or refrain from doing any act;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: that the person’s property be sequestered; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: that the person pay costs.

Heading.TitleText: Administration and Officers of the Court

Section.Text: There shall be kept at the office of the Court in Ottawa, all books and records necessary for recording and entering all proceedings of the Court.

Subsection.Text: The seal of the Court shall be one that has been approved by the Court and shall be kept in the Registry at Ottawa.
If the Chief Justice so authorized there shall be made one or more facsimiles of the seal of the Court to be used as directed by the Chief Justice.
A failure to use the seal as directed shall not invalidate a document unless such failure has resulted in prejudice to the person attacking the validity of the document.
The Registry shall collect the fees prescribed in Schedule II, Tariff A.
Witnesses shall be entitled to be paid the fees and expenses prescribed in Schedule II, Tariff A.
Sheriffs, bailiffs and commissioners shall be entitled to be paid the fees and expenses prescribed in Schedule II, Tariff A.
The Registrar shall charge $0.40 per page for a photocopy of any document on a Court file supplied by the Registrar to a party or other interested person entitled thereto.

Section.Text: In the absence of proof to the contrary, the date of serving or mailing a document sent from the Registry by registered mail is the date that appears on the relevant registration receipt that is kept as part of the records of the Registry.

Section.Text: Subject to section 1.1, for purposes of this Tariff and Tariff B, there are three classes of proceedings as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appeals in which the aggregate of all amounts in issue is less than $50,000, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: appeals in which a loss has been determined under subsection 152(1.1) of the Income Tax Act and the amount that is in issue is less than $100,000; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class B proceedings which include

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: appeals in which the aggregate of all amounts in issue is $50,000 or more but less than $150,000,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: appeals in which a loss has been determined under subsection 152(1.1) of the Income Tax Act and the amount that is in issue is $100,000 or more but less than $300,000,

Paragraph.Label: (c)

Subparagraph.Label: (i)

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)

Section.Text: For the purposes of applying this Tariff and Tariff B with respect to appeals from a determination or redetermination of the fair market value of an object by the Canadian Cultural Property Export Review Board established under the Cultural Property Export and Import Act, or from a confirmation or redetermination of the fair market value of an ecological gift by the Minister of the Environment pursuant to subsection 118.1(10.4) of the Income Tax Act, the three classes of proceedings are as follows:

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) shall come into force on March 15, 1995, and applies to proceedings instituted on or after that date.

A witness, other than a witness who appears to give evidence as an expert, is entitled to be paid by the party who arranged for his or her attendance $75 per day, plus reasonable and proper transportation and living expenses.
An amount is not payable under subsection (1) in respect of an appellant unless the appellant is called upon to testify by counsel for the respondent.

The party who arranges for the attendance of a witness may pay such witness, in lieu of the amount prescribed by subsection 4(1) of this Tariff a larger reasonable amount for attending as witness in that proceeding, but he must, forthwith after he makes such payment, or makes payment of the excess of the amount over the amount provided for in subsection 4(1) of this Tariff, file in the Court Office a statement of that payment and of the way in which he satisfied himself as to the amount payable under this subsection.

When a witness, other than a party, is called on to give evidence in consequence of any professional or technical services rendered by that witness, there shall be substituted for the amount of $75 in subsection 4(1) of this Tariff an amount not exceeding $350 per day subject to increase in the discretion of the taxing officer but otherwise section 4 is applicable to such a witness.

In lieu of making a payment under section 4 of this Tariff, there may be paid to a witness who appears to give evidence as an expert a reasonable payment not exceeding $300 per day, unless the taxing officer otherwise directs, for the services performed by the witness in preparing to give evidence and giving evidence.

Section.Text: No payment shall be made to or received by a witness for what a witness has done in preparing to give evidence or giving evidence except as permitted by this Tariff.

For the purpose of this Tariff, a party arranges for the attendance of a witness by causing a subpoena to be served on the witness or by arranging either directly or indirectly to have the witness attend.

A sheriff or bailiff may take and receive for a service rendered by him the fees or allowances permitted by law for a like service in the superior court of the province (territory) in which the service was rendered.

A commissioner for taking evidence or before whom an examination for discovery is taken or other person performing a similar function, other than a salaried officer of the Court, may be paid by the party who arranged for his services:

Paragraph.Label: (b)

ScheduleFormHeading.Label: SCHEDULE III
ScheduleFormHeading.TitleText: Code of Conduct for Expert Witnesses

Section.Text: An expert witness has an overriding duty to assist the Court impartially on matters relevant to his or her area of expertise.

This duty overrides any duty to a party to the proceeding, including the person retaining the expert witness. An expert witness must be independent and objective and must not be an advocate for a party.
An expert report referred to in subsection 145(1) of the Rules shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the issues addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the qualifications of the expert on the issues addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the expert’s current curriculum vitae attached as a schedule;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the facts and assumptions on which the opinions in the report are based;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the opinions expressed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a report that is provided in response to another expert’s report, an indication of the points of agreement and disagreement with the other expert’s opinions;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for each opinion expressed;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any literature or other materials specifically relied on in support of the opinions;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the methodology used, including any examinations, tests or other investigations on which the expert has relied, including details of the qualifications of the person who carried them out, and whether a representative of any other party was present; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any caveats or qualifications necessary to render the report complete and accurate, including those relating to any insufficiency of data or research and an indication of any matters that fall outside the expert’s field of expertise.

Section.Text: An expert witness must report without delay to persons in receipt of the expert report any material changes affecting the expert’s qualifications or the opinions expressed or the data contained in the expert report.
An expert witness who is ordered by the Court to confer with another expert witness shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exercise independent, impartial and objective judgment on the issues addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: endeavour to clarify with the other expert witness the points on which they agree and those on which their views differ; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: not act on any instruction or request to withhold or avoid agreement with another expert witness.
